title: [Lore Discussion] Jericho Swain and the Direction of Noxus: "Monsters today, Heroes tomorrow."

embed.description: The Special/Hidden/Secret Interactions for the new champion, Swain, the Noxian Grand General. body:
I based a lot of this off the special interactions, as I feel it tells me the most about his character, but if we find new or interesting lore when the PBE updates for his longform stuff, this will be updated. That out of the way, we got Swain's rework and...frankly, it paints Swain and Noxus in a very interesting, telling light. To be blunt: Noxus is no longer the bad guy. They're the guy who gets the job done.

#Swain's New Lore: What we know.

_"I have seen this place. A vision...a battle..."_

Swain, for as far as we know, is still the Grand General of Noxus supplanting Darkwill after his convinent demise. From the looks of it, he still keeps ties with the Black Rose and more. We also know that Swain lost his arm to Irelia during the Ionia-Noxus war and that he's supplanted it with the demonic-empowered arm.

This will be updated with new color lore.

#Swain's Implications: A Tyrant out of Necessity

_"People often ask for a hero when a villain is what they truly need."_

The most fascinating thing I can gleam from Swain's lore, appearance, personality and quotes is that he's not doing this out of hatred. He doesn't loath Demacia. He doesn't despise Bilgewater. Hell, I don't think he even holds ill will to Ionia despite losing to them. What I do see, however, is a man who is acting out of things he knows. Things that are deeper threats.

Take a look at some of his quotes:

>"All roads lead to Noxus...but all visions to Demacia."
>"We both move pawns in a grand game. And look at that; I'm winning."
>"They fight the mist above the seas, never looking beneath it."
>"A pattern, spreading. It has learned to be alive."
>"A king remains in the mist and another marches."

From these quotes, while it could be that Swain gleams them from champion soul taking, it could be inferred that Swain is reading deeper into the lay of the world. He knows things about Runeterra that others would soon forget. Things that require a united front. It also ties into things like Noxus's rapid expansion across the world and the swelling army. Swain knows that trials await and he's preparing the world for them. But the most important part is from his own teaser trailer. Which we'll get into next.

#Swain as a Person: No Hiding the Demon.

_"Your trust may be misplaced, old friend, but it is appreciated."_

Swain makes no efforts to hide that what he's doing is barbaric, cruel and monstrous. Everything he does is done out of necessity for both himself and Noxus. These are most apparent in his lines with LeBlanc but can also be seen elsewhere. Swain is blunt and forthcoming: What he's doing is, for lack of a better word, shitty. But it's something that has to be done. Swain understands on some level that this world won't survive if you all try to hold hands and be a goody goody two-shoes about it. Rather, he's going to be the person who is seen as a tyrant but remembered as a hero. Just take a look at his reveal quote:

>"I have the vision to see what others cannot. The monsters of today will be the heroes of tomorrow. And by my hand will Noxus rise once more."

However, this also means that Swain understands this will only be for the victor. He has to win. He has to be the one standing on the hill at the end of the day. To accomplish this, he has to do everything in his power to make sure that Noxus's flag is the one still waving, even when the world is crumbling around him. This also means he has to keep some less-than-kind bedfellows like the Black Rose. It also means he could discard friends (such as Darius) in a heartbeat. No matter what, in the end, he has to win.

#End Takes

Swain represents the new direction of Noxus. A nation that is not evil for the sake of being evil but recognizes what it takes to win. They're a nation of cuthtroats, backstabbers and cruelty but a nation that recognizes backstabbing today means a hero's welcome tomorrow. I, for one, am excited to see what other champs either fit into this new vision of Noxus or rebel against it.

With that said, feel free to share your thoughts and your own takeaways from Swain's new look and voice.

Noxus has always been focused on power. Power is the only thing that matters in Noxian society. The Swain update hasn't changed Noxus. 

Demacia and Noxus aren't supposed to represent good and evil. They're closer to authoritarianism and anarchy. Both sides are morally gray.

Swain's update has defined Swain's personal reasons to desire power. However, the narrative team has kept the core of Noxus the same.

The thing is, Noxus has been about power but it has tended to be a "cruel" take on power. Take the old lore for example:

* Swain kills Darkwill to ascend.
* Swain publically beheads those who disagree with him.
* Swain does this because **FUCK DEMACIA**
* WOOOOOOOOO NOXUUUUUUUUUUUUUS

Noxus had a tendency to be a caricature of the bad, evil nation compared to Demacia's good, pure nation. Good examples of Noxians (Riven, Talon, Kat) tended to be outcasts or "rebelling" against Noxus. Now, it's a bit more grey.

* You've only listed Swain, someone who isn't representative of all of Noxus
* Murder is relatively commonplace everywhere in Runeterra
---
Demacia and Noxus were meant to be gray from the start.

*  Demacia drafts all its men into the army
*  People tended to die simply during training which is why Demacia is always outnumbered
*  Rule breakers are executed (no minor punishments)
*  Demacia is the most xenophobic nation in Runeterra
*  Woo Demacia. (What was this supposed to mean???)

The problem is when you start comparing other Noxus champions. Remember: Season 1/2/3-ish

* Kat/Talon? Essentially rogue agents and have been seen in old and new lore as counters to Swain.
* Darius and Draven, bloodthirsty executioners in old lore who got a bit of a clean-up in new lore.
* LB and Vladimir, magic users who are pretty darn evil and were painted as such.

etc.

Comparatively, Demacia (Despite the possible under-the-hood evils) was always seen as the good guy. The shining beacon. Hell, there wasn't even subtle undertones of them being evil. They were just good guys. I know this because a huge amount of stuff you list as negatives are _things added in the Demacia update last year_. 

Demacia and Noxus might have been aimed to be grey from the start but it didn't show until the lore updates. Before that, it might as well be Superman and friends vs. the ultra-evil corp of evil.

It was basically good guys vs. bad guys. Now it's more complicated, and Swain, just from what we've seen, has made a far more compelling argument for following him than the Demacia update gave for following Demacia.

What Noxus and it's leadership was and is however, is ambitious, ruthless and extremely harsh on enforcing their rules and leadership on those they beat.

Kinda like a dark magical roman empire, which focuses a lot on merits and skills, particularly after Swain took over.

Back in Old Noxus, during the JoJ, there was an article talking about Noxus' xenophobic attitude towards Yordles. Noxus actually did have issues with outside powers. It's implied that that was why Swain seemed to hide a lot of his powers until the battle at Kalamanda, and even after that rarely using them. Noxians weren't super trusting of outsiders, and who's powers were more "outsider" than a guy turning into a giant demon bird?


I support Noxus, for the most part. I'm not arguing against them. But I'm also not going to deny that they were almost comically evil at times in the Old Lore, outside of a few things with Kat. They stirred up trouble for no reason, treated other nations poorly (they were, admittedly, treated poorly by the other nations as well), and were clearly just meant to be a dark and evil foil to demacia. I appreciate the ruthlessness and ambition that it demands of its citizens, but I'm also going to point out that there were a ton of flaws to it in its old version. It was just a super evil place. It didn't feel a lot like a dark magical roman empire to me because they seemed to just do a lot of bad with no good. They had reasons for invading Ionia, but they were self-serving and probably self-destructive, while new noxus seems to have a much more focused goal and idea of what its place in the world is. It doesn't even feel as much like a counterpart to Demacia, though maybe that'll be proven wrong. It actually feels like its own nation state with its own merits and flaws instead of an evil foil that, even if it was cooler than demacia, was still seemingly just a place to throw the magical bad guys into.

This is correct; Old old noxus -- JoJ era -- was xenophobic against anyone who was strange to them. This was skull mountain era. Thefrostyviking might be thinking of the more recent developments, which are actually still pretty old at this point, come to think of it. That might be why lines seem to be crossed. By the time Sion's rework came around, Noxus was already moving solidly into the "merit for merit's sake" era, we just didn't have the chance to publish a faction update then.

The development of these factions isn't a cut and dry thing and they usually involve some degree of transition, which is why both of you are technically right! For instance, for the Noxian crest, there was an in-between version of it that clearly showed the transition visually. It was still clearly very evil (a fancy version of the JoJ era crest) but it was starting to trend toward the dark+magical style more and had almost purely gothic influences. Later, it developed a blend of gothic+brutalism. Sion's rework happened at the tail end of this transition, which is why his design is consistent with the current Noxian style. 

As for DragonIgnis' original comment that the core of Noxus is the same, yes it is, from Sion's time! Probably not entirely the Noxus from the JoJ time period, though. And since then, we've also worked out more specifics of the nation, so there are new details from when Sion was released. 

Tldr; everyone's technically right, it's just when you were referencing it. Thank goodness we have Universe now.

From my own personal point of view (as a fan and not a rioter), dropping the xenophobic aspect made way for gains in other aspects of Noxus -- like the expansionism and ruthlessness. In my own personal headcanon, I like to imagine that some really really old noxian families still have traces of elitism.

You could just swap the xenophobia for a degree of nationalism instead to a similar effect but it allows for clauses like "if they prove themselves then it's all manners of great"  etc.

And honestly, from my earlier impressions given how Noxus invaded Ionia, they were always both ruthless and expansionist, what was weird was how they were keeping themselves together with a bunch of noble houses that had followed a leader whom Swain killed, it was kinda strange how he kept control of the state with only his own army behind him.

After all, such a nation would have several armies, or legions if you prefer as a reference to the romans, along with SwainÂ´s lines about building roads x)

Which seems to be what Swain did towards Darius and Draven, and he was also "outcast" as he puts it at some point, by whom? Who better than elite noxian nobles looking at him as a useless commoner and cold hearted other commoners looking to just rise up to take his spot.

I'm glad things are going to be caught up soon. There's a lot of good stuff to go around with Noxus. Personally, I like Swain's new Noxus from what I've seen so far. I wouldn't last a day there, but I can see that he's not some two dimensional villain, and someone who provides good reasons to follow him. I'm going to miss a few things (RIP JoJ articles where that one jerk just spewed vitriol towards Noxus, calling them heartless monsters that don't know love and stuff like that. I always hated the guy but loved the articles), but I'm glad to see that Noxus is actually moving into a grey area where there are pros and cons to them, just like Demacia. I feel like Noxus and Demacia will actually be tied together without feeling like forced parallels of each other.

Basically, I think that the lore is definitely a step up from what it used to be, and the moral debate between the ideologies of Noxus and Demacia seem more interesting now that Demacia also has flaws beyond being jerks to the nation that everyone hates. Makes it less of a good vs. bad, more of a lesser of two evils scenario.

My guess is that Swain wants unity through domination and that is not going to work under current circumstances, not with the Void knocking the great gates of Runettera down.Noxus is powerful and big but there are too many power houses at play here,too many oppositions for him.

Time is short,Runeterra is vast, you'd think holding hand is actually the only way to get through something as terrible as Void.

This land is going burn while kings like Jarvan and grand generals like Swain are bickering over domination,thinking they got what it takes to "get things done" ! that makes no one a hero it makes them just another one of many leaders who thought they knew better as their nation burned around them!

i just LOVE this! this makes for an amazing read and a great story to follow!

The issue with handholding is that many of the nations of Runeterra are so self absorbed that there's little chance of them agreeing on anything. Demacia is super xenophobic, with one of its highest ranking soldiers even saying that there was no point in trying to understand the other nations, it's just demacia vs. the rest of the world. Bilgewater has its share of problems. Piltover is full of upper class people who seem to primarily only care about themselves, and Zaun isn't even really a unified city. Azir, meanwhile, is still trying to make Shurima into a promised land while also fighting Xerath and Renekton. Ionia might possibly join with others, but there are still questions about them, especially surrounding the whole Jhin issue. Mount Targon doesn't seem to care much about the rest of the world. They're anti-void, but they seem to be split into several cults, many of which seem to take issue with anyone voicing an opinion that goes against the norm. And Freljord... well, we know what's going on with Freljord

Swain's way of doing things may not be perfect, but from what we've seen of the rest of Runeterra, at least he has an idea of how to unite them. Swain actually seems far more likely to try dominating another country than Demacia, I think. Jarvan and other Demacians don't really seem to relish the thought of going outside their borders. There's scary magic people out there, you know. 

Again, I'm not saying Swain's way of doing things is perfect, far from it, but he at least is working towards his goals. Diplomacy seems like a lost cause on Runeterra, he seems to be taking the approach of uniting the world through the only language everyone appears to understand: overwhelming might.

You make good points, though. I think that the way you're approaching it would work in the real world. Runeterra just seems to be a very different place, stuff that works here just might not work for them.

Yes what you said about each nation is exactly my point as well, too many different views too many different ideas its just like real world, each nation want to do their own thing or just dont care. Noxus is no different either, it is only their leader who see things differently but is that enough?! dictatorship tends to backfire at you at somepoint.

You'd think maybe "if you dont come to some sort of_ temporary_ agreement with others,you all gonna perish" would be enough for them to come off their high horses against something such as Void but no, seems like the alternative is what Swain has in mind. the thing is we cant confirm that threat of void is actually happening and if its happening, you would be a mad man who scream the end of times in streets of Runettera. making people believe ,would be a massive challenge of its own.

Although i understand what Swain wants to do and i relish the thought that at atleast someone knows something big is coming, i dont think sheer overwhelming might is going to work here, because of so many powerful players in Runettera. he need more than Might, because when bloodbath of domination ends how many soldiers are left to fight off whatever is coming next?!

About what you said regarding this approach,that it would  work in real world and not Runettera, im not sure how. i mean we do have records in our history that nations who do not agree with each other come to terms to fight off something bigger. and instead of Galio and other Demigods we have Nuclear bombs and weapons of mass destruction xD

Not everyone gets along in our world, yes, but some groups do get along. We have the U.N. which at least tries to have people working together, and even the U.S. and Russia have worked together on space stuff. There's a history of cooperation. Yes, there are wars, but there are also truces and alliances.

Runeterra seems to have no alliances. It seems more like a bunch of different places that all just want their own thing with no regard for the others. Hell, Demacia especially seems like an easy target for any coming darkness since they seem to almost refuse to leave the safety of their forest, instead sitting and defending. I think that what Swain could do it conquer some places, a slightly easier task since no one is united, and then once that happens he could use his new power to force a peace meeting of some sort. He'd probably just go the domination route, but he could still try for some level of peace.

I think that, in the context of Runeterra and its history at least, Swain's plan has some degree of merit. I think a good display of force is what's necessary to make people listen, trying to warn the other nation states seems sort of like trying to get some screaming children to listen: it's not going to work. If Swain can prove some degree of power, it would probably be easier to get others to listen to him.

In general, we should be skeptical of arguments presented to us, demanding proof at every turn rather than seeking reasons to believe them.

Swain claims that the world is in danger of an apocalyptic invasion.  Besides some whispers and old scrolls, we have no reason to believe that claim, and he certainly has presented no evidence.  Next, he believes that the world will fail to defend itself.  Time and again, it has proven otherwise, defeating all manner of terrible foes.  Last, he argues that only by making him ruler of the world could its forces be marshaled to defeat the coming threat.  That is a self-serving argument from a scheming emperor, and there are plenty of reasonable alternatives.

Swain could have devoted himself to preparing the world for the invasion he claims to foresee.  He could be organizing an alliance, holding meetings, writing plans, recruiting volunteers, and procuring materiÃ¨l.  He has instead lead a massively destructive invasion of the entire planet.  Accordingly, we should read between the lines and of his argument and see it for the pretext it is.

Even if our backs are put to the wall, our lives in the balance in a struggle against some monstrous foe, we should not abandon what made them worth living.  Peace.  Justice.  Freedom.  Let Swain say what he wants about what must be done: these words are worth risking everything for.

While you have a fair point, I think Valoran would be more free and peaceful under the unified rule of Noxus anyway.  While ruthless in war, they're pretty chill after their enemies have surrendered, and Noxians are much more free than Demacians.  For all their screaming about justice, the people of Demacia that aren't grand heroes seem to have no freedoms and live in fear of magic.  No one in any of the other regions is fit to rule all of Valoran.  I do admit that he certainly could have devoted himself to preparing for the invasions in peaceful ways, but it's doubtful they would have worked considering the majority of areas in Runeterra have no ruler.  Swain's way is the only way left.
